frontmatter.title: Advanced topic: Analytical solution of the global Energy Balance Model

abbreviations.EMIC: Earth System Model of Intermediate Complexity

children.value: 1. The zero-dimensional Energy Balance Model: recap

children.label: 1. The zero-dimensional Energy Balance Model: recap

children.value: is the transmissivity of the atmosphere (a measure of the strength of the greenhouse effect).
We have seen that numerical solutions of this time-dependent model are easy to implement. However the model is solvable analytically once we make a (very good) approximation by linearing the
in terms of departures from equilibrium.
The analytical solutions will give us considerable insight into what’s actually going on in the model.
We’ve already seen that the equilibrium solution of the model is

children.html: Teq=((1−α)Qτσ)14T_{eq} = \left( \frac{(1-\alpha) Q}{\tau \sigma} \right)^\frac{1}{4}Teq​=(τσ(1−α)Q​)41​

children.value: and tuned the model parameter based on this re
for small perturbations away from this equilibrium.

Ts′<<TeqT_s^\prime << T_{eq}Ts′​<<Teq​

children.value: Note this this is not a big restriction! For example, a 10 degree warming or cooling is just
Now use a first-order Taylor series expansion to write

children.html: OLR=τσTs4\text{OLR} = \tau \sigma T_s^4OLR=τσTs4​

children.value: OLR = \tau \sigma T_s^4 = \tau \sigma \left( T_{eq} + T_s^\prime \right)^4  \approx \tau \sigma \left( T_{eq}^4 + 4 T_{eq}^3 T_s^\prime \right)
children.html: OLR=τσTs4=τσ(Teq+Ts′)4≈τσ(Teq4+4Teq3Ts′)OLR = \tau \sigma T_s^4 = \tau \sigma \left( T_{eq} + T_s^\prime \right)^4 \approx \tau \sigma \left( T_{eq}^4 + 4 T_{eq}^3 T_s^\prime \right)OLR=τσTs4​=τσ(Teq​+Ts′​)4≈τσ(Teq4​+4Teq3​Ts′​)

children.value: and the budget for the perturbation temperature thus becomes

λ0=4τσTeq3\lambda_0 = 4 \tau \sigma T_{eq}^3λ0​=4τσTeq3​

children.value: Putting in our observational values, we get

OLRobserved = 238.5  # in W/m2
sigma = 5.67E-8  # S-B constant
Tsobserved = 288.  # global average surface temperature
tau = OLRobserved / sigma / Tsobserved**4  # solve for tuned value of transmissivity

lambda_0 = 4 * sigma * tau * Tsobserved**3
#  This is an example of formatted text output in Python
print( 'lambda_0 = {:.2f} W m-2 K-1'.format(lambda_0)  )
This is actually our first estimate of what is often called the
(though the Planck feedback parameter is more properly

children.html: −λ0-\lambda_0−λ0​

children.value: , i.e. a negative number, since it acts as a negative feedback).
It is the tendency for a warm surface to cool by increased
It may also be refered to as the “no-feedback” climate response parameter. As we will see,

children.html: λ0\lambda_0λ0​

children.value: quantifies the sensitivity of the climate system in the absence of any actual feedback processes.

children.html: t∗=Cλ0t^* = \frac{C}{\lambda_0}t∗=λ0​C​

children.value: This is a positive constant with dimensions of time (seconds). With these definitions the temperature evolves according to

Ts′(t)=Ts′(0)exp⁡(−tt∗)T_s^\prime(t) = T_s^\prime(0) \exp \bigg(-\frac{t}{t^*} \bigg)Ts′​(t)=Ts′​(0)exp(−t∗t​)

children.value: I hope that the mathematics is straightforward for everyone in this class. If not, go through it carefully and make sure you understand each step.
4. e-folding time for relaxation of global mean temperature

children.label: 4. e-folding time for relaxation of global mean temperature

children.value: Our model says that surface temperature will relax toward its equilibrium value over a characteristic time scale

children.html: t∗t^*t∗

children.value: – the time it takes for the perturbation to decay by a factor

children.html: 1/e=0.371/e = 0.371/e=0.37

children.value: What should this timescale be for the climate system?

children.html: t∗t^*t∗

children.value: we need a value for the effective heat capacity

children.html: CCC

children.value: Our “quick and dirty” estimate above used 100 meters of water to set this heat capacity.
What is the right choice for water depth

children.html: HHH

children.label: What is the right choice for water depth H?

children.value: That turns out to be an interesting and subtle question. It depends very much on the timescale of the problem
er in the course. For now, let’s just continue assuming

children.html: H=100H = 100H=100

children.value: m (a bit deeper than the typical depth of the surface mixed layer in the oceans).
e the e-folding time for the surface temperature:

c_w = 4E3  #  Specific heat of water in J/kg/K
rho_w = 1E3  #  Density of water in kg/m3
H = 100.   #  Depth of water in m
C = c_w * rho_w * H   #  Heat capacity of the model 

tstar = C / lambda_0   #  Calculated value of relaxation time constant
seconds_per_year = 60.*60.*24.*365.
print( 'The e-folding time is {:1.2e} seconds or about {:1.0f} years.'.format(tstar, tstar / seconds_per_year))

data.name: stdout
data.text: The e-folding time is 1.21e+08 seconds or about 4 years.

children.value: This is a rather fast timescale re
ive to other processes that can affect the planetary energy budget.
But notice that if the climate feedback parameter

children.value: We will come back to this
by linearizing the fourth-power dependence of
The result is a simple exponential decay model.
The system will tend to relax toward its equilibrium temperature on an

children.html: eee

children.value: In our estimate, this e-folding time is re
In the absence of other processes that can either increase the heat capacity or lower (in absolute value) the feedback parameter, the Earth would never be very far out of energy balance.
We will quantify this statement more as the term progresses.
